unnormalised: New Delhi: A nationwide uproar ensued yesterday as the CBSE Class 10 maths paper was leaked online hours before the exam. The leaked paper, circulating on Telegram and WhatsApp groups, contained crucial questions presented in raw LaTeX format. Students reported seeing fragments like "\frac{x^2 + y^2}{2xy}" and "\int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx" without proper rendering, causing widespread panic and confusion.
normalised: New Delhi: A nationwide uproar ensued yesterday as the C-B-S-E Class ten maths paper was leaked online hours before the exam. The leaked paper, circulating on Telegram and WhatsApp groups, contained crucial questions presented in raw L-A-T-E-X format. Students reported seeing fragments like "x squared plus y squared divided by two x y" and "integral from a to b of f of x d x" without proper rendering, causing widespread panic and confusion.

unnormalised: Sources indicate that the leak originated from a coaching center in Kota, Rajasthan. The center allegedly shared the uncompiled LaTeX code with its students, assuming they would be able to interpret the mathematical notation. However, many students unfamiliar with LaTeX found themselves struggling to understand the questions, leading to complaints and accusations of unfair advantage.
normalised: Sources indicate that the leak originated from a coaching center in Kota, Rajasthan. The center allegedly shared the uncompiled L-A-T-E-X code with its students, assuming they would be able to interpret the mathematical notation. However, many students unfamiliar with L-A-T-E-X found themselves struggling to understand the questions, leading to complaints and accusations of unfair advantage.

unnormalised: The CBSE has issued a statement condemning the leak and assuring a thorough investigation. They stated that a re-examination is being considered, but a final decision will be made after assessing the full impact of the incident. The board has also warned against sharing the leaked content, citing legal repercussions under IT Act, section 66. The chaos underscores the need for secure examination protocols and improved awareness regarding LaTeX usage.
normalised: The C-B-S-E has issued a statement condemning the leak and assuring a thorough investigation. They stated that a re-examination is being considered, but a final decision will be made after assessing the full impact of the incident. The board has also warned against sharing the leaked content, citing legal repercussions under I-T Act, section sixty six. The chaos underscores the need for secure examination protocols and improved awareness regarding L-A-T-E-X usage.
